texte:
Symphonie n°1 pour narrateurs et orchestre à vents
une proposition entre musique et arts visuels
I.Still We Drudge in this Dark Maze

maimed civilians
killed, murdered
unknown numbers
soldiers missing too
if only it was someone else’s son
war is the health of the state

who do you believe ?
who do you choose to follow ?
what to believe ?
thousands of memorial to the dead of the past
one memorial to the dead in the future

ignored, irrelevant civilians
or just poor
and peaceful

out-witted, out-bedded, conquered
— they should have known better
losers as fault

I hate war
you love war ?
I love my country
that’s not the same
how do you know — for sure
only sit at my table if I knew your grandfather
I have earned the right to my opinion

Civil War, Great War, World War,
Hundred Years War, Thirty Years War,
War of the Triple Alliance, War on Terror,
Overseas Contingency Operation

there is never one point of view
one interest
one consequence

started and finished
in an instance
pointless,
never-ending,
pause for peace

what images do you remember?
what images do they want you to remember?
forever

— they came in the middle of the night
— they bombed my house
— they left me behind to die
— they started it
— it is their fault

strings for indoors — violin, harp — singing, dancing, flirting
winds for outdoors — trumpets, drums — hunting, fighting, marching

thou shalt not kill
thou shalt love thy neighbour as thyself

war
destruction, profits
hidden artefacts, uncovered, past, present, future

red rose, white rose
red poppy, white poppy

half a million war-related deaths
4,486 dead service men and women

women don't fight wars
bare-breasted, shield-maiden, myth denied,
a peaceful world if run by women

castle
protectors of common people
protected from common people

army
honourable protectors —
uniforms marching, obeying in time
— are people killed in war or do they die?

the battle of Waterloo was won on the playing-fields of Eton;
the opening battles of all subsequent wars have been lost there
man hangs dead on barbed wire
woman raped in front of officials
soldier pours buming wax on woman
pandora's box of death, disease, evil, torture, released

— how do we warn the next generations
— a thousand years in the future?

tub-flies; maggots; impaled; brazen bull; heretic;
fork-head held high; cement shoes; judas cradle;
brown rats; tongue tearer; rack; eaten by crows;
thumbscrew; breast ripper; bleeding; submission;
crocodile shears; republican marriage for nuns and monks; breaking wheel; spanish donkey/wooden
horse; guillotine; prison of terror; crucifixion; rope;
rape; roasting; water boarding
— kind one day; evil the next

false confessions, cheap, on-going
— damage, permanent —
on the pain of death
... this world in arms spends the hopes of its children
I dream of a child who asks: 'what was war, weapons, violence?'
IV. The Larks, Still Bravely Singing

I believe that order is better than chaos,
creation is better than destruction.

I prefer gentleness to violence,
forgiveness to vendetta,
knowledge to ignorance.

candles in the dark of winter
kiss under a full moon
kicking up dead leaves
whirlwind
masterpiece
cups of tea
quiet sunset
my child's first giggle
warm wind touching a tanned cheek
memories
miracles
happy exhaustion
nightingale singing at midnight
fresh sheets
smile from a stranger
joy of expectation

We all breathe the same air.
We all cherish our children's future.
And we are all mortal.
in that rich earth a richer dust
